sub_topic: Solving homogeneous systems of linear equations
message_1:
The problem is as follows:

Solve the following system of homogeneous linear equations:

$$\begin{cases}x+y+z=0\\2x+4y+2z=0\\3x+3y+3z=0 \end{cases}$$

Express your solution as a linear combination of the variables.
message_2:
To solve this system of homogeneous linear equations, we can first simplify the system by dividing the second and third equations by their common factors.

$$\begin{cases}x+y+z=0\\x+2y+z=0\\x+y+z=0 \end{cases}$$

Now, we can see that the first and third equations are the same. We can eliminate the third equation and work with the remaining two equations:

$$\begin{cases}x+y+z=0\\x+2y+z=0 \end{cases}$$

Next, we can eliminate one of the variables by subtracting the first equation from the second equation:

$$(x+2y+z) - (x+y+z) = 0$$
$$y-z=0$$
$$y=z$$

Now, we can express the solution as a linear combination of the variables. Since $y=z$, we can substitute $z$ for $y$ in the first equation:

$$x+z+z=0$$
$$x+2z=0$$
$$x=-2z$$

The solution can be expressed as a linear combination of the variable $z$:

$$\begin{bmatrix}x\\y\\z\end{bmatrix} = z\begin{bmatrix}-2\\1\\1\end{bmatrix}$$

Where $z$ is any scalar.
